reviewText: After all the popularity that Stargate: SG-1 received in its first six years on the air, it was only natural that the creators would want to expand the story with a spin-off series.  As SG-1's seventh season was going on, Stargate: Atlantis was being developed.  Using a plot twist that was introduced at the end of SG-1's seventh season, Atlantis got its start.After searching throughout the Milky Way galaxy for the fabled Lost City of the Ancients (the ancients are a very advanced race of beings that died out long ago), Stargate Command realized that it is on Earth... or at least it was.  The city, which comes to be known as Atlantis, was built on Earth millions of years ago.  The ancients, who as I said are extremely advanced, ot only made it a city, but also made it a spaceship capable of intergalactic travel.  When a great plague hit Earth, some of the ancients evacuated in Atlantis to the Pegasus galaxy, where they plan to start a civilization similar to the one that they had in the Milky Way.Dr. Daniel Jackson (Michael Shanks) of SG-1 eventually finds the correct gate address to Atlantis and an international team of explorers is put together in order to go to and study Atlantis.  The expedition will be led by Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson), a civilian who was very briefly in charge of the SGC.  The Chief Science Officer is Dr. Rodney McKay (David Hewlett), a civilian who has helped out the SGC in the past, the head surgeon is Dr. Carson Beckett (Paul McGillion), a Scottish MD and biologist, and the head of military operations is hardened Col. Summner (Robert Patrick).In order to work most ancient technology efficiently, a rare gene is required, and while Dr. Beckett has it, it isn't pronounced enough to matter.  In comes Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan), a hotshot air force officer with insubordination issues.  Even though he could be a liability to the expedition, he not only has the gene, but can operate the ancient technology almost flawlessly, so he comes along as well.  The last major character is Lt. Aiden Ford (Rainbow Sun Franks), a young officer who looks up to Sheppard (and tragically was born without a personality).Upon arrival in Atlantis, the team realizes that the power is nearly gone, and in order to survive, the city must use the electricity that was powering the defenisve shield to power life support systems.  This also means that they cannot use the gate to go back to Earth, since an intergalactic wormhole requires much more power than normal.Soon, the team begins exploring the city (which is immense) as well as the planets in the galaxy.  On the first planet they visit, they meet Teyla (Rachel Luttrel), a young warrior woman who protects her tribe from something called the Wraith.  When Teyla learns that the visitors don't know who the Wraith are, she begs them to return to where they came from.  Soon, the Wraith show up and a lot of bad things ensue.  The Wraith are a race of beings that actually gave the ancients a good fight!  They are humanoid in build, but they are stronger, faster, and more resistant to harm than any human could hope to be.  Also, humans are their food; they literally suck the life out of people.  Fortunately for the people of the Pegasus galaxy, they only come around every half century or so (most of them hibernate for long periods of time).  Unfortunately, in an act of heroism, Sheppard accidentally causes the entire Wraith population to wake up and begin to feed all at once.That is the pilot episode.  After that, the series becomes somewhat similar to SG-1, where Sheppard and his team go to different planets to make alliances, trade for food, and help people escape the Wraith (I will say that for such a powerful race, Sheppard and co. don't have too much trouble fighting them off).A few story arcs develop this year.  One of them has the Atlantis expedition team get into a bitter rivalry with another advanced race of humans, which leads to an attempted coup on Atlantis.  Also, Beckett begins to study the Wraith and finds out how they came to appear human and how they were able to amass such great numbers.I want to say that even though I'm giving this a 4 star rating, it is definitely a low 4.  The stand-alone episodes were usually moderate; some were good, some were just terrible, but on average, they were just ok.  The story-arc episodes were pretty good, and they showed that Atlantis has a lot of potential as a show.  While there will be a lot to work on, such as writing, character development, and stand-alone quality, after watching the first part of Season 2, I must say that I am very much enjoying where the series is going.  If for no other reason, this set should be watched in order to know what's going on in the later seasons, which so far, appear to be leagues ahead of this one.
summary: A Shaky Start, But It Has Potential

reviewText: I loved the original Stargate series and thought the idea of spinning off the whole Atlantis discovery from the original show was both good writing as going to an entire new Galaxy to explore certainly has enough storyline to support its own show plus as much as I love the original show it had a long good run, but the timing was great to bring closure to the original an this was a natural branching point.  Some of us may have liked to see the transition of some of the characters from the original show, but they did a good job of integrating the plots and use Atlantis to pump new life into the franchise.  The quality of the show stands on the success of the original series by leveraging many of the big discoveries from the original show allowing the off world base that can't easily stargate back and forth to earth make for great starting point to a show that stood on it's own.  Yes, no doubt that Sheppard has many of the personality traits as our original hero, but why kill a good thing?  Being off in another Galaxy somewhat isolated allows for the use and introduction of more of the ancients technology letting teh story grow in a way that the writers don't have to worry about reconciling with modern day earth.  Instead we have a new set of bad guys even nastier than the original, some fresh faces in familiar roles based on the whole stargate structure giving it a powerful launching point from the original show which I think they did an excellent job of building on allowing SG-1 continue on and fade away while Atlantis could grow it's own with new adventures and story lines that leave us able to have technology advances along the way allow for less isolation as the show progresses and their defensive capabilities and understanding of the Wraith continue to increase.  Being a spinoff of a successful show extending the show to a franchise of shows can produce other good shows as we saw with the second generation of Star Trek spinoff's.  Some better than others, but none the less still enough good to be an overall success.  I didn't have time to watch either of these shows when they were on TV so being able to watch them by streaming them allows me to fit them into my time line and watch all the shows, not just the ones I could fit in to my schedule.  So having seen many episodes in the original run I already knew I liked the show, but being able to watch them all allows me to move it a level higher and thoroughly enjoy the show and some of the interesting moral challenges it introduces along with the continual build up of allies, foes, and technology.  Just as in the original series the writing relies on a basic formula for many episodes but they still do a good job of having the show story tie into the overall story and events and choices made earlier.  Having the show start by the team accidentally awakening the Wraith allowed for a super nasty enemy to be found in this new galaxy while introducing secondary effects of it being early that buys time for the team to evolve and not walk into a universe fully infected with Wraith that they would simply be wiped out in (wouldn't have made for much of a show).  The need to protect the location of earth being one of those byproducts introduces the raising of the stakes and the excitement as protecting the outpost suddenly becomes an important underlying need as it protects earth from the under-fed Wraith.  Definitely raising the level of bad guys from other shows as the thought of being harvested and fed on by one of them is truly creepy.  Overall I think the first season did a great job of establishing Stargate Atlantis as its own show that could support itself without a long transition from the original and quickly build an independent story line that could have had a longer run, but still was in my opinion a successful one in terms of science fiction shows go.  It didn't have as long a run as the original, but as far as I've seen so far (and I still have 3 seasons to watch) they did a great job and I can only hope that they are able to end the show without corrupting the franchise legacy (I still have never seen the final episodes).  So for the first season given the perspective of being just over half way through the second I think it is great and the transition handled well.  I'm excited to have 3 more seasons to watch and can only hope the quality remains high and they can write a successful ending in terms of the franchise storyline.  I can only hope that SG Universe is not an indication of where this goes as I thought that show was a significant letdown from the first two as I never became vested in the characters like I did in the original or Atlantis.
summary: Excellent start to an excellent show reviving the Stargate franchise

reviewText: As Rodney utters when Sheppard becomes smitten by the lovely guest star, Leonor Varela in the episode Sanctuary.  This isn't just to poke fun at another Sci-Fi institution, as the writers must clearly see the similarities to that popular franchise.  While the show is a spin-off of Stargate SG-1, it is vastly different, and in my opinion, much closer to a Star Trek series than a parallel to SG-1.The one main similarity the show maintains with SG-1 is that these are modern day, Earth citizens getting into these futuristic, sci-fi adventures.  This aspect makes it very accesible to even the casual sci-fi viewer, as they can easily relate to the main characters, rather than have to rely to much on imagination and future machinations.  Now, don't get me wrong, I love SG-1, but one aspect of the show that seems to weigh it down a bit are a lot of the military base scenes on Earth, with the dull board rooms and office scenery.  Not that I mind non-action sequences, but I think the backgrounds are rather unappealing.  There is nothing like that on Atlantis, as we have new "Ancient" scenery galore on this mystical cityscape.Out of the 20 episodes on this DVD, not one is a dud.  I enjoyed every one, and while a few were somewhat boring, the performances and the building storyline of the season kept my interest rather well.  The first real episode was a slower one, and almost got me thinking that nothing was going to be as good as the stunning pilot, but then I was hit with the incredible tension of the episode Thirty Eight Minutes.  Sheppard and crew are stuck in the Stargate with half the Jumper in and half out, and Sheppard has a life sucking spider on his neck.  This one was excellent.More good episodes abound, including the highlight of disc 2, Childhood's End.  It's a storyline that's been played out in sci-fi dozens of times before (ritual suicide at a young age) but this one is done well, with particularly good performances by the guest actors.  In the last episode on Disc 2, we meet the only other real enemy of the Atlanteans other than the Wraith, the Genii, led by a familiar face in sci fi: Colm Meaney.  We get more of the Genii in season 1, including the two part story arc The Storm and the Eye, but Colm Meaney's character gives way to an equally talented villain, Robert Davi.Disc 4 has two great episodes in Before I Sleep and The Brotherhood.  The former being a dual role for Torri Higginson, playing her older self, and she gives a powerful performance in the older role, almost better than the way she plays the normal Weir!!  No, I like Dr. Weir, I just think she hates being talked out of her orders by Sheppard and comes off as bitter.  In fact, the reason I gave Atlantis a try, was because I liked her performance as Weir in the Season 8 opener of SG-1.  She was much better than the actress who played Weir at the end of SG-1's Season 7.  We also get a neat, Indiana Jones, treasure hunt type episode in the form of Brotherhood, as they have to find where the 15 Brothers hid the ZPM using all sorts of clues and stones left behind, all the while with the dreaded Genii on their trail.We end the season with the build up of the dreaded Wraith heading to Atlantis, wanting to use it to gain access to the wormhole back to Earth.  I like the Wraith as an villain race, and think they were used just about the right amount through the first season.Overall, I think season 1 was an excellent first season, and one of the best for any sci-fi show.  While I haven't seen any of Season 2 yet, I have seen and read about a lot of changes including 2 new cast members, and the departing of Lt. Ford.  I am not sure why this was done so early in the show, but tinkering with something that seemed so good, may be a mistake.  Not many successful shows have a drastic change at the end of the first year.  Most are consistent for the first few years: just look at SG-1, which went 5 seasons before the first main cast change.Back to the Star Trek similarities.  Let's see, you have a macho leading man, who enjoys romancing alien priestesses (John/James T.), a stubborn doctor (McKay/McCoy), a Scottish crew member (Carson/Scotty), a non-Earthling lead crew member (Tayla/Spock), a solid action man (Ford/Sulu), and a setting that takes them to alien worlds (Atlantis/Enterprise).  In Trek they traveled by ship, where here they travel by wormhole.Whatever the similarites to SG-1 or Star Trek, I enjoyed every bit of this new sci-fi show.  The cast, storyline, and setting are all superb.  There is lots of good sci-fi entertainment that can come out of this, let's hope it doesn't go downhill with season 2.One last note, there is absolutely no reason why there shouldn't be chapter stops throughout every episode.  This is very annoying.  I've bought half hour kids' DVD's that have a dozen chapters in them!

reviewText: One of the big arcs of the "Stargate SG-1" series was finding the Lost City of the Ancients, also known as Atlantis.It also turned into fertile fodder for a spinoff series (come on, you KNEW they had to make one eventually), known as "Stargate: Atlantis." The first season has its duds and awkward moments -- much like its parent series -- but it proves to be a solid introduction to likable new heroes, a legendary city, and a new race of alien parasites.At the Antarctic base, Daniel Jackson (Michael Shanks) has finally figured out the location of Atlantis -- in the Pegasus galaxy. General Jack O'Neill (Richard Dean Anderson) gives the go-ahead for an exploratory unit to go to Atlantis -- even though they don't have the power to return back to the Milky Way, and will be stranded there.So Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson) leads an international group of scientists and military to another galaxy, and arrive in the sunken Ancient city of Atlantis. Unfortunately, after ten millennia Atlantis is running out of power, and soon the whole place will flood. The military unit, including Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan), goes scouting for a planet to evacuate to, and encounter the friendly natives.Meanwhile, the irritable scientist Rodney McKay (David Hewlett) tries to somehow salvage the city -- only to have it rise from the ocean floor. But then the SG teams accidentally wake an ancient enemy -- the parasitic, vampiric Wraith, who destroyed the Ancients long ago. Cut off from Earth, the expedition settles into the Ancient city and tries to make the best of their situation.Unfortunately, the Pegasus galaxy has plenty of its own dangers -- an energy-sucking "shadow," possible spies, life-sucking bugs, a destructive nanovirus, a mysterious goddess, suicidal kids, cannibal Wraith, and an Amishlike people who turn out to be ruthless soldiers. And the Wraith are closing in on Atlantis, intent on getting to Earth -- forcing Weir and Sheppard to arm the city for what may be its final stand."Stargate: Atlantis" has an easier introduction than most series, even spinoffs. The whole idea was introduced over a few seasons of "Stargate SG-1," and two of the characters (Weir and McKay) were also recurring characters. And thank God, there is no endless whining about how they may never see Earth again, as many series would do -- the Atlantis personnel just forge ahead, and deal with it.It does have some flaws, mostly the same ones that "SG-1" had in ITS first season -- a few duds ("The romancing of the alien priestess? It's very 1967 of you"), and many others that are good sci-fi watchin', but not great. It takes a little time for the series to get comfortable, but by the last four or five episodes, it really takes off.And it has plenty of sci-fi staples -- ugly nasty aliens, tightly wound scientists, little tubular ships, explosions, moral quandaries and a bit of classic-style horror. But it doesn't lose its laid-back style (Rodney massaging his feet during a conference), or its human side -- for example, one episode has everyone recording touching messages to send back to Earth.And the dialogue is pretty great, with lots of one-liners and snappy exchanges. Most are from Rodney ("This device must be using an older version of Windows"), and Sheppard ("I am your death. That is all you need to know." "I prefer 'Steve'"). But there's humor from everyone ("Find another problem with it! Tell him that the power-loop interface isn't jiving with your walkabout!").The cast is a bit uneven -- Higginson is given too little to do, and Rainbow Sun Francks just never works. But Flanigan has a nice O'Neillian sarcastic snap, Hewlett is hilarious as the mildly antisocial, ever-exasperated scientist, and Paul McGillion is simply adorable as a cuddly Scottish doctor. And while Rachel Luttrell starts off as just the token native love interest, she evolves nicely at the end of the season."Stargate Atlantis" has its shaky moments, and the actors were still getting a grip on their roles. But it's a solid first for a solid sci-fi series, gating out into a new galaxy.

reviewText: For quite a long time, I never liked Stargate; but now, after seeing Atlantis, I realize that I was very wrong. Everything about this show is almost perfect--almost perfect acting, strong storylines, and incredible special effects!First of all, the actors:Joe Flanigan is great as John Sheppard; he gives the character a wry twist, somewhat like Jack O'Neill but a bit less ironic. Rainbow Sun Francks makes Aiden Ford likeable and goodnatured, but willing to take charge when needed. Torri Higginson is better at playing Elizabeth Weir than her SG-1 predecessor, although her character isn't very interesting until the 14th episode. Rachel Luttrell is calm, cool and collected as Teyla. And, of course, David Hewlett, as Rodney McKay, is both annoying, endearing, and hilarious! As for supporting actors, some of the best are Paul McGillion as Dr. Carson Beckett, David Nykl as Dr. Radek Zelenka, and Craig Veroni as Dr. Peter Grodin.Each of the episodes are very well written. SPOILERS FOLLOW for anyone who hasn't seen them!1: Rising. 10/10. This episode starts off the adventure very well, with Daniel Jackson figuring out the riddle of the Lost City. We get to see the city quietly hiding underwater and, even better, erupting upwards in a blaze of sunlight. Colonel Sumner's militaristic personality makes us appreciate Sheppard even more. We meet the Wraith, run away from the Wraith, and in the end realize that we haven't seen the last of them. It sets the stage for the stories to come.2: Hide and Seek. 9/10. Very, very interesting. Of course, it's regrettable that the whole problem was started by some foolish kids, but otherwise it's great. The entire scene with Rodney and his personal shield is one of my favorites!3: Thirty Eight Minutes. 10/10. This has a tense feel to it. Sheppard's strength is ever so slowly being sucked away by a hideous bug, but no one can help him because their 'shuttlecraft', the Puddle Jumper, is stuck in the Stargate! Tensions rise and, surprisingly, the whining Dr. Kavanaugh helps more than he hurts.4: Suspicion. 7/10. Okay, but not one of my favorites. The constant mistrust of Teyla's people, the Athosians, in season 1 gets to be annoying.5: Childhood's End. 9/10. This episode is pretty interesting, involving a group of children and some more Ancient meddling. Sheppard's team gets in trouble, but ends up unscathed.6: Poisoning the Well. 7/10. The biggest problem with this episode is the fact that the Hoffans--a people who are willing to die uselessly in order to keep the Wraith away--are not the only stubborn ones in the Pegasus Galaxy. They totally refuse to find a better way to fight the Wraith, and that is quite frustrating.7: Underground. 8/10. This episode introduces the Genii, militant people who pretend to be farmers and fool even Teyla. Although not one of the best Genii episodes, it's all-around strong, especially with Colm Meaney giving a great performance as Cowen, leader of the Genii.8: Home. 9/10. The team finds a gate with a supposedly unlimited source of power and thinks they can use it to go back to the Milky Way, but of course problems arise. Surprisingly, this episode is not quite as predictable as you might think! Near the end you slowly begin to realize just what's going on, but throughout the entire episode, you're fully in the dark.9: The Storm. 10/10. This is one of the best episodes in the series so far. A giant storm threatens Atlantis--they begin to prepare--but they'll have to fight off the Genii first! Rodney and Dr. Zelenka come up with a great way to temporarily defend the city, and Commander Kolya is introduced. A wonderful episode.10: The Eye. 10/10. The conclusion to The Storm, this is another stellar episode. We see what happens to the city and its inhabitants, and face the Genii. Thankfully, they didn't give the storyline a weak conclusion.11: The Defiant One. 10/10. In this episode, we first see the Ancient Defense Satellite that's featured later on. On the planet below, a single Wraith has survived for ten thousand years and silently waits... Very nerve-wracking and, in a way, sometimes annoying (i.e. the Wraith figuring the Puddle Jumper out in seconds). Rodney's line to Sheppard: "What are you, Captain Kirk?" Great!12: Hot Zone. 10/10. One of, if not the best, episodes of season 1. A contagion is released inside Atlantis and is almost impossible to stop. We get quite a bit of foolishness from Dr. Weir, however, who refuses to sensibly deal with a situation, making Sheppard eventually have to disobey orders in order to resolve it. Thankfully, that doesn't take away from the adventures in this episode.13: Sanctuary. 8/10. An interesting concept, but not so great in the end. After a while, the Ancients lose their luster--stupidly refusing to destroy the Wraith and punishing those Ancients who try to. It doesn't help that the entire episode goes by without the Atlantis team gaining any allies or getting a safe haven to evacuate to.14: Before I Sleep. 10/10. Finally, a Dr. Weir episode that deepens her character! It's too complicated to say much about, but in the end we finally respect and appreciate Elizabeth. A wonderfully complicated time-travel concept helps to add the sci-fi.15: The Brotherhood. 8/10. Sadly, this episode is just like Sanctuary. It leaves Atlantis with absolutely nothing, all because of Rodney's big mouth. In a way, it's slightly frustrating.16: Letters from Pegasus. 10/10. This episode is both escapist and intense. Teyla and Sheppard try to rescue some of the former's friends from the Wraith, while everyone else records messages to send to SGC in a quick data-burst. It shows a hidden side of everyone, which helps to deepen their characters drastically.17: The Gift. 9/10. A secret is revealed, and Teyla becomes even more valuable--in a way. This episode serves to give us more information on her and her people, so it's good to watch.18: The Siege, Part One. 10/10. A wonderful, tense, horrific, and dazzling episode. The Wraith finally come to Atlantis, despite the efforts of Peter Grodin, an intelligent and likeable British doctor, who's regrettably killed when the Wraith destroy the Ancient Defense Satellite. No one knows if they'll survive, and there seems to be no hope.19: The Siege, Part Two. 10/10. Just as good as Part One. A group of Marines show up from SGC, bearing somewhat good news, but in the end it seems that even they won't be good enough to stave off the Wraith. It leaves you nervous and very impatient for Part Three!All in all, Stargate Atlantis is one of the best sci-fi shows I've ever seen. Even if you've never seen SG-1, you should try to get this. You definitely won't be disappointed.

reviewText: I should start by saying that having watched all five seasons, Stargate Atlantis is officially my second favorite science fiction show (the first being Firefly).The first season starts out a bit uncertainly, but by the middle of the season I was fully engaged in the show and its characters.  Interestingly enough, when I went back later and re-watched the beginning of the series, I loved it!  The bottom line is - if it doesn't hook you at first, keep watching.Atlantis is not the best written show I've ever encountered, but its characters are among the most endearing.  The acting is excellent as are the special effects, so I'm willing to forgive the choppy writing.  The flaws it suffers from are common ones: uneven character development, characters magically regenerating from devastating traumas and injuries within the space of a week, characters forced out of character for the sake of a story, and so forth.But putting all of that aside, I truly did fall in love with this show and its characters, who became like a dysfunctional second family.  Some of the highlights:John Sheppard - team leader and military commander of Atlantis. Highly trained, highly intelligent, snarky, brave, loyal and protective of his team above all else, Sheppard is a semi-suicidal hero with a dark past and disdain for authority. Sheppard's character bio might sound trite, but he is played with such delightful, playful expressiveness and complexity by Joe Flanigan that he becomes much more.  The beautifully acted Sheppard is an endearing, flawed, and lovable leader.Dr. Elizabeth Wier - overall expedition leader, in charge of Atlantis Base.  Wier initially seems stiff and reserved, but develops into a smart and likable administrator who even has a positive relationship with the normally defiant Sheppard.  A civilian, Wier lends the expedition a scientific and humanitarian aspect.Dr. Rodney McKay - brilliant physicist and overall tech/science/mechanical genius who is in charge of saving the day whenever Sheppard isn't doing so.  Initially portrayed as a bit of a coward, the insecure, high-strung, arrogant, and self-centered McKay is the show's best layered and developed character.  McKay shows great courage and loyalty in overcoming his fears, and becomes a valuable, endearing member of Sheppard's team.  Despite his arrogance and biting put-downs of co-workers, McKay is also portrayed as one of the most caring and moral people in the expedition.Dr. Carson Beckett - A highly skilled Scottish medical doctor, Carson is in charge of all things medical and also becomes a more and more integral part of Sheppard's team.  Carson is a deeply compassionate, sweet, and caring person that one cannot help but fall in love with, while an inner strength and occasionally biting retorts keep him from being a cream puff in doctor form.  Carson is one of my favorite characters - ever.Lieutenant Aiden Ford - initially a team member, Ford's character never quite developed, and was eventually dropped from the show.Teyla Emmagan - Probably the most cardboard character of the team, Teyla none the less has some great scenes and contributes to the dynamics of the show.  The hot female leader of an alien race of people, she decides that the best bet for her people's future is to leave them and join the Atlantis expedition.  If John Sheppard is the designated eye candy for us female viewers, Teyla is the scantily clad warrior chick for the males.The Wraith - anorexic goth vampires, AKA the Bad Guys.  These nearly indestructible evildoers farm humans like cattle and feed on them by draining their life force in an excruciatingly painful feeding process.  Fond of vengeance and growling noises, the wraith are the number one enemy of the expedition and of the galaxy as a whole.  The wraith would love to find out where earth is so they can snack on it.The Lost City of Atlantis - a submerged/floating/flying city filled with endless undiscovered technology.Along with a well-rounded cast of likable side characters, this team along with some later changes keeps us well entertained for five seasons, at the end of which the show was canceled for no particularly good reason.I grew to love Atlantis, and I hope you'll give yourself a chance to fall in love with it too!
summary: A sci-fi show to fall in love with

reviewText: The creators of "Stargate: SG1" have made yet another fine addition to television science fiction with "Stargate Atlantis". Set far from Earth in the distant Pegasus Galaxy, "Stargate Atlantis" is another finely acted, well-written television series about a team of adventurers traveling across a galaxy via wormholes connected to each other using the Ancients-built stargates. "Stargate Atlantis" is based on a premise established at the end of Season 7 of "Stargate: SG1"; the existence of the long-lost city of the Ancients, Atlantis, which was transported from Earth to the remote Pegasus galaxy many millions of years in the past. Left abandoned for approximately a million years after its citizens fled the vicious Wraith, the city is now home to a team of international, primarily civilian, wormhole travelers, under the command of American diplomat Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson), who was briefly head of Stargate Command (SGC). Cocky U. S. Air Force Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan) leads the main team of Stargate explorers, frequently joined by the  brilliant, but often neurotic, Canadian astrophysicist Dr. Rodney McKay (David Hewlett), widely regarded as the SGC's premier expert on stargate travel.I've been quite impressed with the quality of the acting and of the stories themselves, which have been told often as a series of thrilling episode arcs. It's hard to pick out a few great episodes, but my favorite episodes include "POISONING THE WELL" - featuring brilliant acting by Paul MacGillion as Scottish doctor Dr. Carson Beckett, Stargate Atlantis' chief medical officer, and a tale of such moral dimensions which could have been found on the original "Star Trek" - and "BEFORE I SLEEP", with an impressive performance by Torri Higginson as Dr. Weir.  Overall, the episode quality of "Stargate Atlantis" easily approaches the more recent seasons of "Stargate: SG1". Without question, "Stargate Atlantis" must be regarded as one of the best television science fiction series in current production, with the potential of becoming as memorable as the best "Star Trek" series, if not "Babylon 5".

reviewText: What is Stargate Atlantis?Stargate Atlantis is an offshoot of the popular (though now canceled) television show, Stargate SG-1. It follows the adventures of a band of explorers who enter the Pegasus Galaxy through means of an ancient traveling device known as the Stargate. Once there they find themselves in the lost city of Atlantis, and within several hours of setting up base, they tick off the locals, nearly destroy Atlantis forever, are not able to call back home and awaken the most feared and terrible enemy known to mankind, the Wraith.The team of explorers then come together to create a force against the Wraith, fighting them with all the help Earth is able to give, in terms of both technology and Earth's people, who are shown as caring and brave. They set out to win the hearts of the people of the Pegasus Galaxy, offering help where ever they can, learning new techniques and secrets from a myriad of different cultures and civilizations.Stargate Atlantis is a very good watch. The graphics are very nice, the characters are sci-fi believable and endearing. The Wraith make for some very good bad guys and the story lines are enjoyable. The first season is a little shaky, in terms of figuring out story-lines and character developments, but all issues are quite grounded by the second season.It's not necessary to know or have seen the Stargate SG-1 series to enjoy Stargate Atlantis, as the Stargate SG-1 characters make only a brief cameo appearance in the first episodes of this season. However, in the second and third season of Atlantis, they come in quite a bit more. So some knowledge of the SG-1 is helpful, thought still not necessary to enjoy Atlantis.Little kids will find this show too scary, as the Wraith are a species of albino looking aliens that "feed"  by draining the life force out of humans. Some of the story lines are a little complex for the younger viewer as well. But what you won't find in Atlantis are scantily clad women bearing their all. One of the things that makes Atlantis an awesome show. Respect for the characters.As a connoisseur of Science Fiction, I rate the Stargate series as one of the best on television. Endearing characters, enjoyable story-lines and great graphics all add up to make this the kind of show you want to have in your collection.

reviewText: Stargate Atlantis seems destined to follow Deep Space Nine in terms of the middle child of sci-fi franchises. They are alone and dealing with a completely new enemy, the awesome Wraith, as well as a few equally evil humans, the Geni.  This feeling of being completely on their own with everything feeling new lends creedence to the "explorer" theme of stargate far better. Atlantis has atlantis and themselves, and must make do.Better yet, this show truly takes from the classic sci-fi of olden days. I can watch Sheppard and McKay banter all day long.  Frankly, in terms of scientist characters, McKay is easily my favorite of all sci-fi.  He may be a bit of jerk, but his performance is likeably and fun enough to warrant you truly liking the character.  Anyway, I've said too much, but I highly recomend you give this show a try if you haven't the first season sets a great precedent, and is one of the more entertaining shows you'll see.

reviewText: I think we have SG-1 to thank for the strong, running start Atlantis was given. Because we didn't have to do what SG-1 did--which was introduce nearly the entire concept of the Stargate to audiences--we had a strong foundation already created for the sister show. However, Atlantis did very well at not closely mimicking its predecessor but taking an idea already created and expanding it, literally, into an entirely new galaxy.Though I still hold that season 2 is probably the best of all five SGA seasons, season 1 gave Atlantis the strong foundation it needed to become a truly remarkable television series. The characters were strong and evolved over the course of twenty episodes to become people we could really relate with, care for, love, hate, sympathize with, laugh with and hurt for. As I will always openly admit, McKay is my favorite character and I thought he got a great start with episodes like Hide and Seek, The Storm and the Eye, The Brotherhood, Home, The Defiant One and Hot Zone. However, this was also a great season for seeing John Sheppard really come into being as a great character, especially in all the episodes mentioned above. Season one really saw the beginning of what becomes, what I think is, one of the greatest friendships in the Stargate universe.One of the things that made this season so great (and so different from all the others) is the concept of this team of explorers being completely isolated from their predecessors. With literally almost no ties to the show that began it all, season one of Stargate Atlantis was allowed to come into its own with nearly no interference from the show that began it all. I think that is one of the things that really helped make SGA strong. SG-1 was a great show, one of the best and hard to beat, but we needed to know that we were not just getting a repeat of the first eight seasons of SG-1 set in another galaxy. I think fans were pacified after the first few episodes.Season one was nearly perfect as an introductory season. The writers, cast and crew did a wonderful job at giving us something both familiar and unique.

reviewText: This marvelous spin off of STARGATE SG-1 does so many things so very, very well.  STARGATE ATLANTIS expands and continues much of the rich mythology built up by SG-1 by delving into greater and great detail into the Ancients.  In fact, looking at the two shows it is safe to say that the Goa'uld storyline that drove the first eight seasons of SG-1 has given way in both ATLANTIS and SG-1 to exploring the Ancients.  In SG-1 this has involved fighting the Ori, who threaten the Ancients as ascended beings, while in ATLANTIS this has involved encountering and fighting the Wraith, the enemy that millennia before caused the Ancients to ascend to begin with.ATLANTIS was able to hit the ground running in part because of the richness of the mythology created in the parent show and in part because of the number of SG-1 veterans in the production crew.  Most of the ATLANTIS writers also work on SG-1, including Peter Deluise.  One wonders how Deluise manages to find time to sleep, given the staggering number of SG-1 and ATLANTIS episodes that he has either directed or written.The cast, on the other hand, is a different matter.  Only one regular character was familiar to SG-1 fans, Dr. Rodney McKay (wonderfully performed by David Hewlett).  He had appeared on a few episodes of SG-1 as an exceedingly high strung, grating, but brilliant expert on the physics of stargates.  He instantly became one of the best things on the new show, marvelously blending technical mastery in key plot developments with a host of quirks that makes him equally adept at comic relief.  The most curious casting development was the appearance of Torri Higginson as Dr. Elizabeth Weir.  This was curious because when the character was first introduced on SG-1 at the end of Season Eight, Weir was played by Sci-fi veteran actress Jessica Steen, who did a great job.  I've heard multiple reasons for why Steen was replaced by Higginson, though the one that seems to make the most sense is that Steen declined the role because he would have meant moving to Vancouver.  Whatever the truth, both actresses have performed the role wonderfully, and Torri Higginson is a major asset to ATLANTIS.  The show is technically headlined by Joe Flanigan, who does a great job as Maj. John Sheppard.  He brings a lot of the same qualities to that role that Ben Browder brings to SG-1, though in somewhat less animated form.  Rachel Luttrell is fine as Teyla, an inhabitant of a world they visit shortly after finding Atlantis.  The only problem with the opening credits characters was Rainbow Sun Francks as Lt. Aiden Ford.  One of the soldiers and a member of Sheppard's team (along with McCray and Teyla), his character simply never developed.  It was as if the writers could never figure out what to do with him to make him interesting and vital, and eventually he was more or less written off the show (though he has returned after Season One in guest roles).  There were several other crucial supporting characters, in particular Paul McGillion as Dr. Carson Beckett.  Like Scotty in the original STAR TREK he speaks in a Scottish accent, but his is somewhat honestly come by, having been born in Scotland though raised in Canada.  One actor who doesn't get quite the acknowledgment he deserves is James Lafazanos, who portrays all of the male Wraiths on the show.The art direction on ATLANTIS is simply outstanding.  The city of Atlantis is brilliantly conceived and fascinating to look at.  Many of the world's they visit are fascinating.  One of the presuppositions of the show is that the Pegasus galaxy, where Atlantis is found, is dominated by the Wraith, vampire like creatures who feed off the life force of humans, but who spend considerable stretches of time hibernating.  As a result, most of the civilizations our heroes visit are considerably less developed than those found by the SG-1 team.  Also, it is a far less rich galaxy, sporting only humans and Wraiths, instead of the variety of races on SG-1.The first season wasn't perfect, but it was remarkably engaging from the very beginning.  The only real miss was the character of Lt. Ford (the fault of the writers, not the actor).  The season ended with the first two parts of a three-part extravaganza, with a titanic struggle between Atlantis's human defenders against a massive onslaught of Wraith.  The special effects in these three episodes probably surpass anything that was ever done on SG-1 and led to a riveting ending of a great first season.Many shows have had spin offs, but I think the SG-1/ATLANTIS pair rival any other pair short of BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER/ANGEL.  Many spin offs are only lightly coordinated with the original, but that is not the case here.  In Season Two and so far in Season Three the ties between the two shows have dramatically increased and promise to be even tighter in the future.
summary: A wonderful spin off of one of Sci-fi's best series

reviewText: As far as I am concerned, this boxed set is at the higher-end of mediocre spectrum.In the show, The Ancients, the builders of the stargates and ancestor of modern humans left in a city-ship called Atlantis to the Pegasus galaxy and never returned.  10 million years later, an international team of scientists and military go on a one-way trip to Pegasus and discover the city underpowered, underwater, unihabited and hidden from Pegasus' version of thte Goa'uld: The Wraith.PROS: The interior design and cover art is pretty good (in contrast to the box cover).  There are 4 episodes per disc, and each one is in 1.78:1 aspect ratio; the episodes themselves are 1.5-1.6GB in size, the same size as the disappointing MACGYVER boxed set episodes, but definitely better.  The sound, image, color and transfer is crisp, clean, smooth and polished with pixellation visible at 40X magnification.  Beautiful.  Audio commentaries on plenty of episodes even though I haven't listend to them all yet.CONS: The cover box art is disappointing; I'd expect that design from overseas collections.  There are no bonus features aside from obligatory and sparse production documentation, so bloopers, deleted scenes and the like are out.WORST: Forget about skipping through episodes to get to your favorite parts: THERE ARE NO CHAPTER STOPS PAST THE SHOWS INTRODUCTION; skip ahead from chapter 3 and you'll end up at the credits.*NOTE* Reports about a Disc 5 glitch have been listed: allegedly, some sets may contain a Disc 5 that has Episodes 1-4 RE-printed on it instead of 17-20.  My set is fine, but you might want to look into this report.These things and the final one especially stripped the 5th star from my review.Other than that, this is one of the better spin-offs and this is definitely one of the better Season 1's you'll find (thanks to franchise budgets).  The quality of the image, compactness of the box and tone of story make this set worth the buy.

reviewText: This spin-off is awesome, almost just as good as SG-1. The amazing thing about Atlantis is that if you compare their first season to SG-1's first season, this is so much greater(probably because of the fact that the writers are the same and know what they are doing now). The first season of Atlantis is as developed and great as say, the third or fourth season of SG-1. Imagine what it will be like on their sixth or seventh season. One thing lacking is more character development, which was also lacking from the second season, but the writers realized that and they are going to make the third season mainly about characters-with an episode completely about Weir on earth and an episode about Sheppard's backstory and one with McKay and his sister. I really liked Lt.Ford and at first I was kind of dissapointed about what they did to him in the second season, but it grew on me. This is an outstanding season or show in general, when I saw the pilot, I did'nt really understand or like it-so I held off on watching the show until the DVD came out, by then I had bought all of the seasons of SG-1 and caught up on the story, I then bought the pilot and loved it, when I saw the entire season I was amazed at how good it was-it is a great show. I recommend it to anyone who likes SG-1 or just loves Sci-fi in general. Sheppard, McKay, and Ford are my favorite characters-I think the new guy, Ronin(introduced in the second season) will grow on me. Great episodes in this season include: Rising p1 and p2, Thirty-eight minutes, Suspicion, Poisoning the Well, Underground, Home, The Storm, The Eye, Hot Zone, Before I Sleep, The Brotherhood, Letters from Pegasus, The Gift, The Siege p1 and p2. ENJOY!!!
